messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:23): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: any suggestions for a shorter term than "valid URL potentially surrounded by spaces"?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (08:24): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: "valid URL attribute value" is a little shorter (assuming that is equally accurate)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (08:24): or even just "URL attribute value" if there is no need for the non-valid version
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:25): i'd rather not call the syntax by where it's used
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:26): that always ends up giving me trouble later when i reuse the syntaxes
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (08:29): "space-delimited URL"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:32): i'll just go with potentially surrounded by spaces, it's less ambiguous
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (08:42): it does seem like a pretty unambiguous choice
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:53): me tries to figure out which way the wind blowing on adding presence of role=presentation as an exception to the alt-required constraint
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (08:53): morning good chaps & ladies.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:54): if it is favorable I could add it speculatively/experimentally now to the checker in the interest of giving something broader to test against
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:54): or I could hold off and just do it for now as close to the existing spec as I can get
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (08:55): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: if it weren't for the variations in spellings, we'd have the same first/last names.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (08:56): your first name has a (tm) in it also?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:04): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: the role=presentation exception is pointless... it's longer than the alternative (just writing alt="", which implied role=presentation automatically)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:04): s/implied/implies/
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:06): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: besides, mine's more trademarkable
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:07): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: OK

ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:07): hey, 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e thanks for the slight tip last night on where to look for the protocol details on websockets, so far I've got the server accepting clients and reading the headers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:07): cool
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:07): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: your parents clearly have more imagination than mine
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:08): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: how about aria-labelledby ?

ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:09): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I've been working from a slightly different use case, so far all the server's I've seen don't make use of the path in the initial GET request
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:09): is it intended to be used?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:09): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=6496
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:09): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:09): er
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:10): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: cool, do you know of any other servers they make use of it?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:11): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: i wrote one that does, but it's a hack :-) (i used it to smuggle in the username/password of the user, instead of sending it in the first frame)
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:11): so far most I've seen don't even parse the headers correctly
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:11): yeah
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:11): because, theoretically there aren't any headers not allowed
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:12): plus, they use a fixed order for them, which isn't correct

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:12): that's why the latest draft requires the servers to parse two headers, because otherwise the servers wouldn't parse any and would be vulnerable to a cross-protocol attack from HTTP
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I see, thanks (about aria-labelledby)
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:13): two headers? I've missed that one.. I'll have to check up on it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:13): the two Sec-WebSocket-Key headers

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:13): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: as a general rule, ARIA is a layer above HTML, so it should be possible to take any HTML file with ARIA, remove all the ARIA, and not make the page less conforming
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:13): oh, I thought they were part of the first GET request
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:14): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: by "header" i meant "field" in websocket terminology, my bad
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (09:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: yeah, that does seems rational, thanks
